appendix.title: Function Reference
appendix.para: This appendix provides a list of all the functions which are currently defined in Gnumeric.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bitwise and

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BITAND returns the bitwise and of the binary representations of its arguments.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bit-shift to the left

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BITLSHIFT returns the binary representations of a shifted n positions to the left.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If n is negative, BITLSHIFT shifts the bits to the right by ABS(n) positions.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bitwise or

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BITOR returns the bitwise or of the binary representations of its arguments.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bit-shift to the right

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BITRSHIFT returns the binary representations of a shifted n positions to the right.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If n is negative, BITRSHIFT shifts the bits to the left by ABS(n) positions.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bitwise exclusive or

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BITXOR returns the bitwise exclusive or of the binary representations of its arguments.

refnamediv.refpurpose: a complex number of the form x + yi

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: i: the suffix for the complex number, either "i" or "j"; defaults to "i"

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If i is neither "i" nor "j", COMPLEX returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: the absolute value of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the imaginary part of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arccosine of the complex number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCCOS returns the complex arccosine of the complex number z. The branch cuts are on the real axis, less than -1 and greater than 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arccosine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCCOSH returns the complex hyperbolic arccosine of the complex number z. The branch cut is on the real axis, less than 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arccotangent of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arccotangent of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arccosecant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arccosecant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arcsecant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arcsecant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arcsine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCSIN returns the complex arcsine of the complex number z. The branch cuts are on the real axis, less than -1 and greater than 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arcsine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCSINH returns the complex hyperbolic arcsine of the complex number z. The branch cuts are on the imaginary axis, below -i and above i.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex arctangent of the complex number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCTAN returns the complex arctangent of the complex number z. The branch cuts are on the imaginary axis, below -i and above i.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex hyperbolic arctangent of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IMARCTANH returns the complex hyperbolic arctangent of the complex number z. The branch cuts are on the real axis, less than -1 and greater than 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the argument theta of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The argument theta of a complex number is its angle in radians from the real axis.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex conjugate of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the cosine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic cosine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the cotangent of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refsect1.title: Note

refnamediv.refpurpose: the quotient of two complex numbers z1/z2

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z1 or z2 is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the exponential of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the factorial of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the gamma function of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the incomplete Gamma function

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: lower: if true (the default), the lower incomplete gamma function, otherwise the upper incomplete gamma function
regularize: if true (the default), the regularized version of the incomplete gamma function

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The regularized incomplete gamma function is the unregularized incomplete gamma function divided by gamma(a)

refnamediv.refpurpose: the reciprocal, or inverse, of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the natural logarithm of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The result will have an imaginary part between -π and +π.
The natural logarithm is not uniquely defined on complex numbers. You may need to add or subtract an even multiple of π to the imaginary part.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the base-10 logarithm of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the base-2 logarithm of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the negative of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the complex number z1 raised to the z2th power

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z1 or z2 is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the product of the given complex numbers

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If any of z1, z2,... is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the real part of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the secant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic secant of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the sine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic sine of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the square root of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the difference of two complex numbers

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z1 or z2 is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the sum of the given complex numbers

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If any of z1, z2,... is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the tangent of the complex number z

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic tangent of the complex number z

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If z is not a valid complex number, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: average of the values in field in database belonging to records that match criteria

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: database: a range in which rows of related information are records and columns of data are fields
field: a string or integer specifying which field is to be used

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: database is a range in which rows of related information are records and columns of data are fields. The first row of a database contains labels for each column.

field is a string or integer specifying which field is to be used. If field is an integer n then the nth column will be used. If field is a string, then the column with the matching label will be used.

criteria is a range containing conditions. The first row of a criteria should contain labels. Each label specifies to which field the conditions given in that column apply. Each cell below the label specifies a condition such as ">3" or "<9". An equality condition can be given by simply specifying a value, e. g. "3" or "Jody". For a record to be considered it must satisfy all conditions in at least one of the rows of criteria.

refnamediv.refpurpose: summary data from a pivot table

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: pivot_table: cell range containing the pivot table
field_name: name of the field for which the summary data is requested

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the summary data is unavailable, GETPIVOTDATA returns #REF!

refnamediv.refpurpose: Ascension Thursday in the Gregorian calendar according to the Roman rite of the Christian Church

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: year between 1582 and 9956, defaults to the year of the next Ascension Thursday

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Two digit years are adjusted as elsewhere in Gnumeric. Dates before 1904 may also be prohibited.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Ash Wednesday in the Gregorian calendar according to the Roman rite of the Christian Church

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: year between 1582 and 9956, defaults to the year of the next Ash Wednesday

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Two digit years are adjusted as elsewhere in Gnumeric. Dates before 1904 may also be prohibited.

refnamediv.refpurpose: create a date serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The DATE function creates date serial values. 1-Jan-1900 is serial value 1, 2-Jan-1900 is serial value 2, and so on. For compatibility reasons, a serial value is reserved for the non-existing date 29-Feb-1900.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If month or day is less than 1 or too big, then the year and/or month will be adjusted. For spreadsheets created with the Mac version of Excel, serial 1 is 1-Jan-1904.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hebrew date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: date: Gregorian date, defaults to today

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hebrew date in Hebrew

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: date: Gregorian date, defaults to today

refnamediv.refpurpose: Julian day number for given Gregorian date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: date: Gregorian date, defaults to today

refnamediv.refpurpose: the Unix timestamp corresponding to a date d

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The DATE2UNIX function translates a date into a Unix timestamp. A Unix timestamp is the number of seconds since midnight (0:00) of January 1st, 1970 GMT.

refnamediv.refpurpose: difference between dates

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DATEDIF returns the distance from start_date to end_date according to the unit specified by interval.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If interval is "y", "m", or "d" then the distance is measured in complete years, months, or days respectively. If interval is "ym" or "yd" then the distance is measured in complete months or days, respectively, but excluding any difference in years. If interval is "md" then the distance is measured in complete days but excluding any difference in months.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the date part of a date and time serial value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: serial: date and time serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DATEVALUE returns the date serial value part of a date and time serial value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the day-of-month part of a date serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The DAY function returns the day-of-month part of date.

refnamediv.refpurpose: difference between dates in days

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DAYS returns the positive or negative number of days from start_date to end_date.

refnamediv.refpurpose: days between dates

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DAYS360 returns the number of days from start_date to end_date.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If method is 0, the default, the MS Excel (tm) US method will be used. This is a somewhat complicated industry standard method where the last day of February is considered to be the 30th day of the month, but only for start_date. If method is 1, the European method will be used. In this case, if the day of the month is 31 it will be considered as 30 If method is 2, a saner version of the US method is used in which both dates get the same February treatment.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Easter Sunday in the Gregorian calendar according to the Roman rite of the Christian Church

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: year between 1582 and 9956, defaults to the year of the next Easter Sunday

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Two digit years are adjusted as elsewhere in Gnumeric. Dates before 1904 may also be prohibited.

refsect1.title: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Compatibility
refsect1.para: The 1-argument version of EASTERSUNDAY is compatible with OpenOffice for years after 1904. This function is not specified in ODF/OpenFormula.

refnamediv.refpurpose: adjust a date by a number of months

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EDATE returns date moved forward or backward the number of months specified by months.

refnamediv.refpurpose: end of month

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EOMONTH returns the date serial value of the end of the month specified by date adjusted forward or backward the number of months specified by months.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Good Friday in the Gregorian calendar according to the Roman rite of the Christian Church

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: year between 1582 and 9956, defaults to the year of the next Good Friday

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Two digit years are adjusted as elsewhere in Gnumeric. Dates before 1904 may also be prohibited.

day: Gregorian day of month, defaults to the current day

refnamediv.refpurpose: Julian day number for given Gregorian date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: Gregorian year of date, defaults to the current year
month: Gregorian month of year, defaults to the current month
day: Gregorian day of month, defaults to the current day

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hebrew month of Gregorian date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: Gregorian year of date, defaults to the current year
month: Gregorian month of year, defaults to the current month
day: Gregorian day of month, defaults to the current day

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hebrew year of Gregorian date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: Gregorian year of date, defaults to the current year
month: Gregorian month of year, defaults to the current month
day: Gregorian day of month, defaults to the current day

refnamediv.refpurpose: compute hour part of fractional day

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time of day as fractional day

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The HOUR function computes the hour part of the fractional day given by time.

refnamediv.refpurpose: ISO week number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ISOWEEKNUM calculates the week number according to the ISO 8601 standard. Weeks start on Mondays and week 1 contains the first Thursday of the year.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: January 1 of a year is sometimes in week 52 or 53 of the previous year. Similarly, December 31 is sometimes in week 1 of the following year.

refnamediv.refpurpose: year corresponding to the ISO week number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ISOYEAR calculates the year to go with week number according to the ISO 8601 standard.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: January 1 of a year is sometimes in week 52 or 53 of the previous year. Similarly, December 31 is sometimes in week 1 of the following year.

refnamediv.refpurpose: compute minute part of fractional day

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time of day as fractional day

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The MINUTE function computes the minute part of the fractional day given by time.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the month part of a date serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The MONTH function returns the month part of date.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of workdays in range

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: weekend: array of 0s and 1s, indicating whether a weekday (S, M, T, W, T, F, S) is on the weekend, defaults to {1,0,0,0,0,0,1}

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NETWORKDAYS calculates the number of days from start_date to end_date skipping weekends and holidays in the process.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If an entry of weekend is non-zero, the corresponding weekday is not a work day.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if the last argument is omitted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the date and time serial value of the current time

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The NOW function returns the date and time serial value of the moment it is computed. Recomputing later will produce a different value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: create a time serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The ODF.TIME function computes the time given by hour, minute, and second as a fraction of a day.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While the return value is automatically formatted to look like a time between 0:00 and 24:00, the underlying serial time value can be any number.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Pentecost Sunday in the Gregorian calendar according to the Roman rite of the Christian Church

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: year: year between 1582 and 9956, defaults to the year of the next Pentecost Sunday

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Two digit years are adjusted as elsewhere in Gnumeric. Dates before 1904 may also be prohibited.

refnamediv.refpurpose: compute seconds part of fractional day

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time of day as fractional day

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The SECOND function computes the seconds part of the fractional day given by time.

refnamediv.refpurpose: create a time serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The TIME function computes the fractional day after midnight at the time given by hour, minute, and second.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While the return value is automatically formatted to look like a time between 0:00 and 24:00, the underlying serial time value is a number between 0 and 1. If any of hour, minute, and second is negative, #NUM! is returned

refnamediv.refpurpose: the time part of a date and time serial value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: serial: date and time serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TIMEVALUE returns the time-of-day part of a date and time serial value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the date serial value of today

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The TODAY function returns the date serial value of the day it is computed. Recomputing on a later date will produce a different value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: date value corresponding to the Unix timestamp t

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The UNIX2DATE function translates Unix timestamps into the corresponding date. A Unix timestamp is the number of seconds since midnight (0:00) of January 1st, 1970 GMT.

refnamediv.refpurpose: day-of-week

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The WEEKDAY function returns the day-of-week of date. The value of method determines how days are numbered; it defaults to 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If method is 1, then Sunday is 1, Monday is 2, etc. If method is 2, then Monday is 1, Tuesday is 2, etc. If method is 3, then Monday is 0, Tuesday is 1, etc. If method is 11, then Monday is 1, Tuesday is 2, etc. If method is 12, then Tuesday is 1, Wednesday is 2, etc. If method is 13, then Wednesday is 1, Thursday is 2, etc. If method is 14, then Thursday is 1, Friday is 2, etc. If method is 15, then Friday is 1, Saturday is 2, etc. If method is 16, then Saturday is 1, Sunday is 2, etc. If method is 17, then Sunday is 1, Monday is 2, etc.

refnamediv.refpurpose: week number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: WEEKNUM calculates the week number according to method which defaults to 1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If method is 1, then weeks start on Sundays and January 1 is in week 1. If method is 2, then weeks start on Mondays and January 1 is in week 1. If method is 150, then the ISO 8601 numbering is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: add working days

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: days: number of days to add
weekend: array of 0s and 1s, indicating whether a weekday (S, M, T, W, T, F, S) is on the weekend, defaults to {1,0,0,0,0,0,1}

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: WORKDAY adjusts date by days skipping over weekends and holidays in the process.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: days may be negative. If an entry of weekend is non-zero, the corresponding weekday is not a work day.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if the last argument is omitted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the year part of a date serial value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The YEAR function returns the year part of date.

refnamediv.refpurpose: fractional number of years between dates

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: YEARFRAC calculates the number of days from start_date to end_date according to the calendar specified by basis, which defaults to 0, and expresses the result as a fractional number of years.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: string of digits representing the number n in base b

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: length: minimum length of the resulting string

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BASE converts n to its string representation in base b. Leading zeroes will be added to reach the minimum length given by length.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Modified Bessel function of the first kind of order α at x

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x or α are not numeric, #VALUE! is returned. If α < 0, #NUM! is returned.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if only integer orders α are used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Bessel function of the first kind of order α at x

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x or α are not numeric, #VALUE! is returned. If α < 0, #NUM! is returned.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if only integer orders α are used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Modified Bessel function of the second kind of order α at x

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x or α are not numeric, #VALUE! is returned. If α < 0, #NUM! is returned.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if only integer orders α are used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Bessel function of the second kind of order α at x

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x or α are not numeric, #VALUE! is returned. If α < 0, #NUM! is returned.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if only integer orders α are used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: decimal representation of the binary number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a binary number, either as a string or as a number involving only the digits 0 and 1

refnamediv.refpurpose: hexadecimal representation of the binary number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a binary number, either as a string or as a number involving only the digits 0 and 1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, BIN2HEX pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, BIN2HEX returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: octal representation of the binary number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a binary number, either as a string or as a number involving only the digits 0 and 1

refsect1.para: If places is given, BIN2OCT pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, BIN2OCT returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: a converted measurement

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CONVERT returns a conversion from one measurement system to another. x is a value in from units that is to be converted into to units.
from and to can be any of the following:
For metric units any of the following prefixes can be used:

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If from and to are different types, CONVERT returns #N/A!

refnamediv.refpurpose: binary representation of the decimal number x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given and x is non-negative, DEC2BIN pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, DEC2BIN returns #NUM!
If places is given and x is negative, places is ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x < − 512 or x > 511, DEC2BIN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: hexadecimal representation of the decimal number x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, DEC2HEX pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, DEC2HEX returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: octal representation of the decimal number x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, DEC2OCT pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, DEC2OCT returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: decimal representation of x
Kronecker delta function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DELTA returns 1 if x1 = x0 and 0 otherwise.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If either argument is non-numeric, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Gauss error function

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: lower: lower limit of the integral, defaults to 0
upper: upper limit of the integral

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ERF returns 2/sqrt(π)* integral from lower to upper of exp(-t*t) dt

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is Excel compatible if two arguments are supplied and neither is negative.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Complementary Gauss error function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ERFC returns 2/sqrt(π)* integral from x to ∞ of exp(-t*t) dt

refnamediv.refpurpose: step function with step at x1 evaluated at x0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GESTEP returns 1 if x1 ≤ x0 and 0 otherwise.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If either argument is non-numeric, #VALUE! is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: binary representation of the hexadecimal number x
