refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, HEX2BIN pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, HEX2BIN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: decimal representation of the hexadecimal number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a hexadecimal number, either as a string or as a number if no A to F are needed

refnamediv.refpurpose: octal representation of the hexadecimal number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a hexadecimal number, either as a string or as a number if no A to F are needed

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, HEX2OCT pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, HEX2OCT returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: hexadecimal representation of numeric value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HEXREP returns a hexadecimal string representation of x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This is a function meant for debugging. The layout of the result may change and even depend on how Gnumeric was compiled.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the reciprocal of the sum of reciprocals of the arguments

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INVSUMINV sum calculates the reciprocal (the inverse) of the sum of reciprocals (inverses) of all its arguments.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If any of the arguments is negative, #VALUE! is returned.
If any argument is zero, the result is zero.

refnamediv.refpurpose: binary representation of the octal number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a octal number, either as a string or as a number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, OCT2BIN pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, OCT2BIN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: decimal representation of the octal number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a octal number, either as a string or as a number

refnamediv.refpurpose: hexadecimal representation of the octal number x

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: a octal number, either as a string or as a number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If places is given, OCT2HEX pads the result with zeros to achieve exactly places digits. If this is not possible, OCT2HEX returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of circuits required

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DIMCIRC returns the number of circuits required given traffic calls with grade of service gos.

refnamediv.refpurpose: traffic capacity

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OFFCAP returns the traffic capacity given circuits circuits with grade of service gos.

refnamediv.refpurpose: predicted number of offered calls

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OFFTRAF returns the predicted number of offered calls given traffic carried calls (taken from measurements) on circuits circuits.

refnamediv.refpurpose: probability of blocking

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PROBBLOCK returns probability of blocking when traffic calls load into circuits circuits.

refnamediv.refpurpose: accrued interest

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: first_interest: date of first interest payment
frequency: number of interest payments per year
calc_method: calculation method, defaults to TRUE

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If first_interest < settlement and calc_method is TRUE, then ACCRINT returns the sum of the interest accrued in all coupon periods from issue date until settlement date.
If first_interest < settlement and calc_method is FALSE, then ACCRINT returns the sum of the interest accrued in all coupon periods from first_interest date until settlement date.
Otherwise ACCRINT returns the sum of the interest accrued in all coupon periods from issue date until settlement date.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency must be one of 1, 2 or 4, but the exact value does not affect the result. issue must precede both first_interest and settlement. frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: accrued interest

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ACCRINTM calculates the accrued interest from issue to maturity.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: par defaults to $1000. If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset using French accounting conventions

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AMORDEGRC calculates the depreciation of an asset using French accounting conventions. Assets purchased in the middle of a period take prorated depreciation into account. This is similar to AMORLINC, except that a depreciation coefficient is applied in the calculation depending on the life of the assets.
1.0 for an expected lifetime less than 3 years,
1.5 for an expected lifetime of at least 3 years but less than 5 years,
2.0 for an expected lifetime of at least 5 years but at most 6 years,
2.5 for an expected lifetime of more than 6 years.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Special depreciation rules are applied for the last two periods resulting in a possible total depreciation exceeding the difference of cost - salvage. Named for AMORtissement DEGRessif Comptabilite. If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset using French accounting conventions

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AMORLINC calculates the depreciation of an asset using French accounting conventions. Assets purchased in the middle of a period take prorated depreciation into account.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Named for AMORtissement LINeaire Comptabilite. If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of days from coupon period to settlement

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPDAYBS calculates the number of days from the beginning of the coupon period to the settlement date.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of days in the coupon period of the settlement date

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPDAYS calculates the number of days in the coupon period of the settlement date.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of days from the settlement date to the next coupon period

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPDAYSNC calculates number of days from the settlement date to the next coupon period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the next coupon date after settlement

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPNCD calculates the coupon date following settlement.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of coupons

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPNUM calculates the number of coupons to be paid between the settlement and maturity dates, rounded up.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the last coupon date before settlement

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUPPCD calculates the coupon date preceding settlement.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: cumulative bivariate normal distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: a: limit for first random variable
b: limit for second random variable
rho: correlation of the two random variables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CUM_BIV_NORM_DIST calculates the probability that two standard normal distributed random variables with correlation rho are respectively each less than a and b.

refnamediv.refpurpose: cumulative interest payment

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: start_period: first period to accumulate for
end_period: last period to accumulate for

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CUMIPMT calculates the cumulative interest paid on a loan from start_period to end_period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: cumulative principal

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: start_period: first period to accumulate for
end_period: last period to accumulate for

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CUMPRINC calculates the cumulative principal paid on a loan from start_period to end_period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: month: number of months in first year of depreciation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DB calculates the depreciation of an asset for a given period using the fixed-declining balance method.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: factor: factor at which the balance declines

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DDB calculates the depreciation of an asset for a given period using the double-declining balance method.

refnamediv.refpurpose: discount rate

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DISC calculates the discount rate for a security.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: redemption is the redemption value per $100 face value. If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: convert to decimal dollar amount

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DOLLARDE converts a fractional dollar amount into a decimal amount. This is the inverse of the DOLLARFR function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: convert to dollar fraction

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DOLLARFR converts a decimal dollar amount into a fractional amount which is represented as the digits after the decimal point. For example, 2/8 would be represented as .2 while 3/16 would be represented as .03. This is the inverse of the DOLLARDE function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the (Macaulay) duration of a security

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DURATION calculates the (Macaulay) duration of a security.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: effective interest rate

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: nper: number of periods used for compounding

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EFFECT calculates the effective interest rate using the formula (1+rate/nper)^nper-1.

refnamediv.refpurpose: equivalent of 1 EUR

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EURO calculates the national currency amount corresponding to 1 EUR for any of the national currencies that were replaced by the Euro on its introduction.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: currency must be one of ATS (Austria), BEF (Belgium), CYP (Cyprus), DEM (Germany), EEK (Estonia), ESP (Spain), EUR (Euro), FIM (Finland), FRF (France), GRD (Greece), IEP (Ireland), ITL (Italy), LUF (Luxembourg), MTL (Malta), NLG (The Netherlands), PTE (Portugal), SIT (Slovenia), or SKK (Slovakia). This function is not likely to be useful anymore.

refnamediv.refpurpose: pre-Euro amount from one currency to another

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: full_precision: whether to provide the full precision; defaults to false
triangulation_precision: number of digits (at least 3) to be rounded to after conversion of the source currency to euro; defaults to no rounding

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EUROCONVERT converts n units of currency source to currency target. The rates used are the official ones used on the introduction of the Euro.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If full_precision is true, the result is not rounded; if it false the result is rounded to 0 or 2 decimals depending on the target currency; defaults to false. source and target must be one of the currencies listed for the EURO function. This function is not likely to be useful anymore.

refnamediv.refpurpose: future value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: rate: effective interest rate per period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FV calculates the future value of pv moved nper periods into the future, assuming a periodic payment of pmt and an interest rate of rate per period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: future value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FVSCHEDULE calculates the future value of principal after applying a range of interest rates with compounding.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the duration of a investment

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: G_DURATION calculates the number of periods needed for an investment to attain a desired value.

refsect1.title: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Compatibility
refsect1.para: G_DURATION is the OpenFormula function PDURATION.

refnamediv.refpurpose: interest rate

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INTRATE calculates the interest of a fully vested security.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: interest payment for period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IPMT calculates the interest part of an annuity's payment for period number per.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: internal rate of return

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: guess: an estimate of what the result should be

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: IRR calculates the internal rate of return of a cash flow with periodic payments. values lists the payments (negative values) and receipts (positive values) for each period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The optional guess is needed because there can be more than one valid result. It defaults to 10%.

refnamediv.refpurpose: interest payment for period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ISPMT calculates the interest payment for period number per.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the modified (Macaulay) duration of a security

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MDURATION calculates the modified (Macaulay) duration of a security.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: modified internal rate of return

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: finance_rate: interest rate for financing cost

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MIRR calculates the modified internal rate of return of a periodic cash flow.

refnamediv.refpurpose: nominal interest rate

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: nper: number of periods used for compounding

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NOMINAL calculates the nominal interest rate from the effective rate.

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of periods

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NPER calculates the number of periods of an investment based on periodic constant payments and a constant interest rate.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: net present value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: rate: effective interest rate per period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NPV calculates the net present value of a cash flow.

refnamediv.refpurpose: price of a security that has an odd first period

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ODDFPRICE calculates the price per $100 face value of a security that pays periodic interest, but has an odd first period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a security that has an odd first period

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ODDFYIELD calculates the yield of a security that pays periodic interest, but has an odd first period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: price of a security that has an odd last period

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ODDLPRICE calculates the price per $100 face value of a security that pays periodic interest, but has an odd last period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a security that has an odd last period

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ODDLYIELD calculates the yield of a security that pays periodic interest, but has an odd last period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of options on 2 assets with correlation rho

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
spot1: spot price of the underlying asset of the first option
spot2: spot price of the underlying asset of the second option
strike1: strike prices of the first option
strike2: strike prices of the second option
time: time to maturity in years
cost_of_carry1: net cost of holding the underlying asset of the first option (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
cost_of_carry2: net cost of holding the underlying asset of the second option (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
volatility1: annualized volatility in price of the underlying asset of the first option
volatility2: annualized volatility in price of the underlying asset of the second option
rho: correlation between the two underlying assets

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_2_ASSET_CORRELATION models the theoretical price of options on 2 assets with correlation rho. The payoff for a call is max(spot2 - strike2,0) if spot1 > strike1 or 0 otherwise. The payoff for a put is max (strike2 - spot2, 0) if spot1 < strike1 or 0 otherwise.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of an American option to exchange assets

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time to maturity in years
cost_of_carry1: net cost of holding asset 1 (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
cost_of_carry2: net cost of holding asset 2 (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
volatility1: annualized volatility in price of asset 1
volatility2: annualized volatility in price of asset 2
rho: correlation between the prices of the two assets

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_AMER_EXCHANGE models the theoretical price of an American option to exchange one asset with quantity qty2 and spot price spot2 for another with quantity qty1 and spot price spot1.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: OPT_EURO_EXCHANGE, OPT_BS, OPT_BS_DELTA, OPT_BS_RHO, OPT_BS_THETA, OPT_BS_GAMMA.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of an option according to the Barone Adesie & Whaley approximation

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in days
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of either an American or European style option using a binomial tree

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: amer_euro_flag: 'a' for an American style option or 'e' for a European style option
call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
num_time_steps: number of time steps used in the valuation
time: time to maturity in years
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: A larger num_time_steps yields greater accuracy but OPT_BINOMIAL is slower to calculate.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of American options according to the Bjerksund & Stensland approximation technique

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in days
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refnamediv.refpurpose: price of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the price of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The returned value will be expressed in the same units as strike and spot.

refnamediv.refpurpose: elasticity of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_CARRYCOST uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'elasticity' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot. The elasticity of an option is the rate of change of its price with respect to its cost_of_carry.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Elasticity is expressed as the rate of change of the option value, per 100% volatility.

refnamediv.refpurpose: delta of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_DELTA uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'delta' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The returned value will be expressed in the same units as strike and spot.

refnamediv.refpurpose: gamma of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_GAMMA uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'gamma' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot. The gamma of an option is the second derivative of its price with respect to the price of the underlying asset.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Gamma is expressed as the rate of change of delta per unit change in spot. Gamma is the same for calls and puts.

refnamediv.refpurpose: rho of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_RHO uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'rho' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot. The rho of an option is the rate of change of its price with respect to the risk free interest rate.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Rho is expressed as the rate of change of the option value, per 100% change in rate.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theta of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_THETA uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'theta' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot. The theta of an option is the rate of change of its price with respect to time to expiry.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Theta is expressed as the negative of the rate of change of the option value, per 365.25 days.

refnamediv.refpurpose: vega of a European option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time to maturity in years
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_BS_VEGA uses the Black-Scholes model to calculate the 'vega' of a European option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot. The vega of an option is the rate of change of its price with respect to volatility.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Vega is the same for calls and puts. Vega is expressed as the rate of change of option value, per 100% volatility.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a complex chooser option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: strike_call: strike price, if exercised as a call option
strike_put: strike price, if exercised as a put option
time: time in years until the holder chooses a put or a call option
time_call: time in years to maturity of the call option if chosen
time_put: time in years to maturity of the put option if chosen
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a European option to exchange assets

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: time: time to maturity in years
cost_of_carry1: net cost of holding asset 1 (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
cost_of_carry2: net cost of holding asset 2 (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield)
volatility1: annualized volatility in price of asset 1
volatility2: annualized volatility in price of asset 2
rho: correlation between the prices of the two assets

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_EURO_EXCHANGE models the theoretical price of a European option to exchange one asset with quantity qty2 and spot price spot2 for another with quantity qty1 and spot price spot1.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: OPT_AMER_EXCHANGE, OPT_BS, OPT_BS_DELTA, OPT_BS_RHO, OPT_BS_THETA, OPT_BS_GAMMA.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of executive stock options

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in days
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The model assumes executives forfeit their options if they leave the company.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of extendible writer options

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
strike1: strike price at which the option is struck
strike2: strike price at which the option is re-struck if out of the money at time1
time1: initial maturity of the option in years
time2: extended maturity in years if chosen
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_EXTENDIBLE_WRITER models the theoretical price of extendible writer options. These are options that have their maturity extended to time2 if the option is out of the money at time1.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a fixed-strike lookback option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
spot_min: minimum spot price of the underlying asset so far observed
spot_max: maximum spot price of the underlying asset so far observed
time: time to maturity in years
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_FIXED_STRK_LKBK determines the theoretical price of a fixed-strike lookback option where the holder of the option may exercise on expiry at the most favourable price observed during the options life of the underlying asset.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of floating-strike lookback option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
spot_min: minimum spot price of the underlying asset so far observed
spot_max: maximum spot price of the underlying asset so far observed
time: time to maturity in years
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_FLOAT_STRK_LKBK determines the theoretical price of a floating-strike lookback option where the holder of the option may exercise on expiry at the most favourable price observed during the options life of the underlying asset.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of forward start options

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
alpha: fraction setting the strike price at the future date time_start
time_start: time until the option starts in days
time: time to maturity in days
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a European option adjusted for trading day volatility

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: ratio of the number of calendar days to exercise and the number of calendar days in the year
ttime: ratio of the number of trading days to exercise and the number of trading days in the year
rate: risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset (for common stocks, the risk free rate less the dividend yield), defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_FRENCH values the theoretical price of a European option adjusted for trading day volatility, struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a European currency option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: number of days to exercise
domestic_rate: domestic risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
foreign_rate: foreign risk-free interest rate to the exercise date in percent
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_GARMAN_KOHLHAGEN values the theoretical price of a European currency option struck at strike on an asset with spot price spot.

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of an option according to the Jump Diffusion process

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time: time to maturity in years
rate: the annualized rate of interest
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date
lambda: expected number of 'jumps' per year
gamma: proportion of volatility explained by the 'jumps'

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_JUMP_DIFF models the theoretical price of an option according to the Jump Diffusion process (Merton).

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of options on commodities futures according to Miltersen & Schwartz

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
p_t: zero coupon bond with expiry at option maturity
t1: time to maturity of the option
t2: time to maturity of the underlying commodity futures contract
v_s: volatility of the spot commodity price
v_e: volatility of the future convenience yield
v_f: volatility of the forward rate of interest
rho_se: correlation between the spot commodity price and the convenience yield
rho_sf: correlation between the spot commodity price and the forward interest rate
rho_ef: correlation between the forward interest rate and the convenience yield
kappa_e: speed of mean reversion of the convenience yield
kappa_f: speed of mean reversion of the forward interest rate

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of options on options

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: type_flag: 'cc' for calls on calls, 'cp' for calls on puts, and so on for 'pc', and 'pp'
strike1: strike price at which the option being valued is struck
strike2: strike price at which the underlying option is struck
time1: time in years to maturity of the option
time2: time in years to the maturity of the underlying option
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset of the underlying option
volatility: annualized volatility in price of the underlying asset of the underlying option

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: For common stocks, cost_of_carry is the risk free rate less the dividend yield. time2 ≥ time1

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of an American option according to the Roll-Geske-Whaley approximation

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: d: amount of the dividend to be paid expressed in currency
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset in percent for the period through to the exercise date

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a simple chooser option

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
time1: time in years until the holder chooses a put or a call option
time2: time in years until the chosen option expires
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of a European option on the spread between two futures contracts

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
fut_price1: price of the first futures contract
fut_price2: price of the second futures contract
time: time to maturity in years
volatility1: annualized volatility in price of the first underlying futures contract
volatility2: annualized volatility in price of the second underlying futures contract
rho: correlation between the two futures contracts

refnamediv.refpurpose: theoretical price of time switch options

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: call_put_flag: 'c' for a call and 'p' for a put
a: amount received for each time period
time: time to maturity in years
m: number of time units the option has already met the condition
dt: agreed upon discrete time period expressed as a fraction of a year
cost_of_carry: net cost of holding the underlying asset
volatility: annualized volatility of the asset

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OPT_TIME_SWITCH models the theoretical price of time switch options. (Pechtl 1995). The holder receives a * dt for each period that the asset price was greater than strike (for a call) or below it (for a put).

refnamediv.refpurpose: payment for annuity

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PMT calculates the payment amount for an annuity.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: interest payment for period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PPMT calculates the principal part of an annuity's payment for period number per.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: price of a security

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PRICE calculates the price per $100 face value of a security that pays periodic interest.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: discounted price

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: discount: annual rate at which to discount

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PRICEDISC calculates the price per $100 face value of a bond that does not pay interest at maturity.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: price at maturity

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: discount: annual rate at which to discount

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PRICEMAT calculates the price per $100 face value of a bond that pays interest at maturity.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: present value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: rate: effective interest rate per period

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PV calculates the present value of fv which is nper periods into the future, assuming a periodic payment of pmt and an interest rate of rate per period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: rate of investment

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: guess: an estimate of what the result should be

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RATE calculates the rate of return.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period. The optional guess is needed because there can be more than one valid result. It defaults to 10%.

refnamediv.refpurpose: amount to be received at maturity

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RECEIVED calculates the amount to be received when a security matures.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: equivalent interest rate for an investment increasing in value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RRI determines an equivalent interest rate for an investment that increases in value. The interest is compounded after each complete period.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period. Note that p need not be an integer but for fractional value the calculated rate is only approximate.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SLN calculates the depreciation of an asset using the straight-line method.

refnamediv.refpurpose: sum-of-years depreciation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SYD calculates the depreciation of an asset using the sum-of-years method.

refnamediv.refpurpose: bond-equivalent yield for a treasury bill

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: discount: annual rate at which to discount

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TBILLEQ calculates the bond-equivalent yield for a treasury bill.

refnamediv.refpurpose: price of a treasury bill

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: discount: annual rate at which to discount

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TBILLPRICE calculates the price per $100 face value for a treasury bill.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a treasury bill

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TBILLYIELD calculates the yield of a treasury bill.

refnamediv.refpurpose: depreciation of an asset

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: start_period: first period to accumulate for
end_period: last period to accumulate for
factor: factor at which the balance declines
no_switch: do not switch to straight-line depreciation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VDB calculates the depreciation of an asset for a given period range using the variable-rate declining balance method.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If no_switch is FALSE, the calculation switches to straight-line depreciation when depreciation is greater than the declining balance calculation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: internal rate of return

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: guess: an estimate of what the result should be

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: XIRR calculates the annualized internal rate of return of a cash flow at arbitrary points in time. values lists the payments (negative values) and receipts (positive values) with one value for each entry in dates.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The optional guess is needed because there can be more than one valid result. It defaults to 10%.

refnamediv.refpurpose: net present value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: XNPV calculates the net present value of a cash flow at irregular times

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If type is 0, the default, payment is at the end of each period. If type is 1, payment is at the beginning of each period.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a security

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: frequency: number of interest payments per year

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: YIELD calculates the yield of a security that pays periodic interest.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: frequency may be 1 (annual), 2 (semi-annual), or 4 (quarterly). If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a discounted security

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: YIELDDISC calculates the yield of a discounted security.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: yield of a security

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: YIELDMAT calculates the yield of a security for which the interest is paid at maturity date.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If basis is 0, then the US 30/360 method is used. If basis is 1, then actual number of days is used. If basis is 2, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are considered only 360 days. If basis is 3, then actual number of days is used within a month, but years are always considered 365 days. If basis is 4, then the European 30/360 method is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the current version of Gnumeric

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GNUMERIC_VERSION returns the version of gnumeric as a string.

refnamediv.refpurpose: information of type about cell

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: type: string specifying the type of information requested

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: type specifies the type of information you want to obtain:
address Returns the given cell reference as text.
col Returns the number of the column in cell.
contents Returns the contents of the cell in cell.
column Returns the number of the column in cell.
coord Returns the absolute address of cell.
filename Returns the name of the file of cell.
format Returns the code of the format of the cell.
locked Returns 1 if cell is locked.
parentheses Returns 1 if cell contains a negative value
and its format displays it with parentheses.
prefix Returns a character indicating the horizontal
protect Returns 1 if cell is locked.
row Returns the number of the row in cell.
sheetname Returns the name of the sheet of cell.
type Returns "l" if cell contains a string,
"v" if it contains some other value, and
value Returns the contents of the cell in cell.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the number of blank cells in range
the error with the given name
the type of error

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ERROR.TYPE returns an error number corresponding to the given error value. The error numbers for error values are:

refnamediv.refpurpose: expression in cell as a string

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If cell contains no expression, EXPRESSION returns empty.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the formula in cell as a string

refsect1.title: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Compatibility
refsect1.para: GET.FORMULA is the OpenFormula function FORMULA.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the target of the hyperlink attached to cell as a string

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The value return is not updated automatically when the link attached to cell changes but requires a recalculation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the value of execution environment variable name

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: name: the name of the environment variable

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If a variable called name does not exist, #N/A! will be returned. Variable names are case sensitive.

refnamediv.refpurpose: information about the current operating environment according to type

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: type: string giving the type of information requested

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INFO returns information about the current operating environment according to type:
memavail Returns the amount of memory available, bytes.
memused Returns the amount of memory used (bytes).
numfile Returns the number of active worksheets.
osversion Returns the operating system version.
release Returns the version of Gnumeric as text.
system Returns the name of the environment.
totmem Returns the amount of total memory available.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TRUE if value is blank

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function checks if a value is blank. Empty cells are blank, but empty strings are not.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TRUE if value is any error value except #N/A
TRUE if value is any error value
TRUE if n is even
TRUE if cell contains a formula
TRUE if value is a logical value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function checks if a value is either TRUE or FALSE.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TRUE if value is the #N/A error value
TRUE if value is not text
TRUE if value is a number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function checks if a value is a number. Neither TRUE nor FALSE are numbers for this purpose.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TRUE if n is odd
TRUE if value is a reference

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function checks if a value is a cell reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TRUE if value is text
text converted to a number

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If text contains non-numerical text, 0 is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the error value #N/A
a number indicating the data type of value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TYPE returns a number indicating the data type of value:

refnamediv.refpurpose: logical conjunction

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AND calculates the logical conjunction of its arguments b0,b1,...

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If an argument is numerical, zero is considered FALSE and anything else TRUE. Strings and empty values are ignored. If no logical values are provided, then the error #VALUE! is returned. This function is strict: if any argument is an error, the result will be the first such error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the value FALSE
conditional expression

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: trueval: value to use if condition is true
falseval: value to use if condition is false

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function first evaluates the condition. If the result is true, it will then evaluate and return the second argument. Otherwise, it will evaluate and return the last argument.

refnamediv.refpurpose: test for error

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: value to test for error

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the first value, unless that is an error, in which case it returns the second.

refnamediv.refpurpose: test for #NA! error

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: value to test for #NA! error

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the first value, unless that is #NA!, in which case it returns the second.

refnamediv.refpurpose: logical negation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NOT calculates the logical negation of its argument.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the argument is numerical, zero is considered FALSE and anything else TRUE. Strings and empty values are ignored.

refnamediv.refpurpose: logical disjunction

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OR calculates the logical disjunction of its arguments b0,b1,...

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If an argument is numerical, zero is considered FALSE and anything else TRUE. Strings and empty values are ignored. If no logical values are provided, then the error #VALUE! is returned. This function is strict: if any argument is an error, the result will be the first such error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the value TRUE
logical exclusive disjunction

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: XOR calculates the logical exclusive disjunction of its arguments b0,b1,...

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If an argument is numerical, zero is considered FALSE and anything else TRUE. Strings and empty values are ignored. If no logical values are provided, then the error #VALUE! is returned. This function is strict: if any argument is an error, the result will be the first such error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: cell address as text

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: abs_num: 1 for an absolute, 2 for a row absolute and column relative, 3 for a row relative and column absolute, and 4 for a relative reference; defaults to 1
a1: if TRUE, an A1-style reference is provided, otherwise an R1C1-style reference; defaults to TRUE
text: name of the worksheet, defaults to no sheet

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If row_num or col_num is less than one, ADDRESS returns #VALUE! If abs_num is greater than 4 ADDRESS returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of areas in reference
vertical array of the arguments
the (index+1)th argument

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: index is truncated to an integer. If index < 1 or the truncated index > number of values, CHOOSE returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: vector of column numbers

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: reference, defaults to the position of the current expression

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COLUMN function returns a Nx1 array containing the sequence of integers from the first column to the last column of x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: column number for the given column called name

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If name is invalid, COLUMNNUMBER returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of columns in reference

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If reference is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, COLUMNS returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: matrix flipped

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: vertical: if true, matrix is flipped vertically, otherwise horizontally; defaults to TRUE

refnamediv.refpurpose: search the first row of range for value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: row: 1-based row offset indicating the return values
approximate: if false, an exact match of value must be found; defaults to TRUE
as_index: if true, the 0-based column offset is returned; defaults to FALSE

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HLOOKUP function finds the row in range that has a first cell similar to value. If approximate is not true it finds the column with an exact equality. If approximate is true, it finds the last column with first value less than or equal to value. If as_index is true the 0-based column offset is returned.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If approximate is true, then the values must be sorted in order of ascending value. HLOOKUP returns #REF! if row falls outside range.

refnamediv.refpurpose: second or first arguments

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HYPERLINK function currently returns its 2nd argument, or if that is omitted the 1st argument.

refnamediv.refpurpose: reference to a cell in the given array

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: area: from which area to select a cell, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INDEX gives a reference to a cell in the given array. The cell is selected by row and col, which count the rows and columns in the array.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the reference falls outside the range of array, INDEX returns #REF!

refnamediv.refpurpose: contents of the cell pointed to by the ref_text string

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: format: if true, ref_text is given in A1-style, otherwise it is given in R1C1 style; defaults to true

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If ref_text is not a valid reference in the style determined by format, INDIRECT returns #REF!

refnamediv.refpurpose: contents of vector2 at the corresponding location to value in vector1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If vector1 has more rows than columns, LOOKUP searches the first row of vector1, otherwise the first column. If vector2 is omitted the return value is taken from the last row or column of vector1.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If LOOKUP can't find value it uses the largest value less than value. The data must be sorted. If value is smaller than the first value it returns #N/A. If the corresponding location does not exist in vector2, it returns #N/A.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the index of seek in vector

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: vector: n by 1 or 1 by n range to be searched
type: +1 (the default) to find the largest value ≤ seek, 0 to find the first value = seek, or-1 to find the smallest value ≥ seek

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MATCH searches vector for seek and returns the 1-based index.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: For type = -1 the data must be sorted in descending order; for type = +1 the data must be sorted in ascending order. If seek could not be found, #N/A is returned. If vector is neither n by 1 nor 1 by n, #N/A is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: an offset cell range

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: row: number of rows to offset range
col: number of columns to offset range
height: height of the offset range, defaults to height of range
width: width of the offset range, defaults to width of range

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: OFFSET returns the cell range starting at offset (row,col) from range of height height and width width.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If range is neither a reference nor a range, OFFSET returns #VALUE!

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: COLUMN, COLUMNS, ROWS, INDEX, INDIRECT, ADDRESS.

refnamediv.refpurpose: vector of row numbers

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: reference, defaults to the position of the current expression

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ROW function returns a 1xN array containing the sequence of integers from the first row to the last row of x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of rows in reference

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If reference is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, ROWS returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: sheet number of reference

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: reference: reference or literal sheet name, defaults to the current sheet

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If reference is neither a reference nor a literal sheet name, SHEET returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: number of sheets in reference

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: reference: array, reference, or range, defaults to the maximum range

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If reference is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, SHEETS returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: sorted list of numbers as vertical array

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: order: 0 (descending order) or 1 (ascending order); defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Strings, booleans, and empty cells are ignored.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the transpose of matrix
search the first column of range for value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: column: 1-based column offset indicating the return values
approximate: if false, an exact match of value must be found; defaults to TRUE
as_index: if true, the 0-based row offset is returned; defaults to FALSE

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VLOOKUP function finds the row in range that has a first cell similar to value. If approximate is not true it finds the row with an exact equality. If approximate is true, it finds the last row with first value less than or equal to value. If as_index is true the 0-based row offset is returned.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If approximate is true, then the values must be sorted in order of ascending value. VLOOKUP returns #REF! if column falls outside range.

refnamediv.refpurpose: absolute value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ABS gives the absolute value of x, i.e. the non-negative number of the same magnitude as x.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the arc cosine of x
the hyperbolic arc cosine of x
inverse cotangent of x
the inverse hyperbolic cotangent of x
the Roman numeral roman as number

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Any Roman symbol to the left of a larger symbol (directly or indirectly) reduces the final value by the symbol amount, otherwise, it increases the final amount by the symbol's amount.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the arc sine of x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASIN calculates the arc sine of x; that is the value whose sine is x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x falls outside the range -1 to 1, ASIN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: the inverse hyperbolic sine of x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASINH calculates the inverse hyperbolic sine of x; that is the value whose hyperbolic sine is x.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the arc tangent of x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATAN calculates the arc tangent of x; that is the value whose tangent is x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The result will be between −π/2 and +π/2.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the arc tangent of the ratio y/x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATAN2 calculates the direction from the origin to the point (x,y) as an angle from the x-axis in radians.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The result will be between −π and +π. The order of the arguments may be unexpected.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the inverse hyperbolic tangent of x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATANH calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of x; that is the value whose hyperbolic tangent is x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the absolute value of x is greater than 1.0, ATANH returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: average of the cells in actual range for which the corresponding cells in the range meet the given criteria

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: criteria: condition for a cell to be included
actual_range: cell area, defaults to range

refnamediv.refpurpose: Euler beta function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETA function returns the value of the Euler beta function extended to all real numbers except 0 and negative integers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x, y, or (x + y) are non-positive integers, BETA returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: natural logarithm of the absolute value of the Euler beta function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETALN function returns the natural logarithm of the absolute value of the Euler beta function extended to all real numbers except 0 and negative integers.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x, y, or (x + y) are non-positive integers, BETALN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: smallest integer larger than or equal to x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CEIL(x) is the smallest integer that is at least as large as x.

refsect1.title: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is the OpenFormula function CEILING(x).

refnamediv.refpurpose: nearest multiple of significance whose absolute value is at least ABS(x)

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: significance: base multiple (defaults to 1 for x > 0 and -1 for x <0)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CEILING(x,significance) is the nearest multiple of significance whose absolute value is at least ABS(x).

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x or significance is non-numeric, CEILING returns a #VALUE! error. If x and significance have different signs, CEILING returns a #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Compatibility
refsect1.para: CEILING(x) is exported to ODF as CEILING(x,SIGN(x),1). CEILING(x,significance) is the OpenFormula function CEILING(x,significance,1).

refnamediv.refpurpose: the Cholesky decomposition of the symmetric positive-definite matrix

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: matrix: a symmetric positive definite matrix

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the Cholesky-Banachiewicz algorithm applied to matrix fails, Cholesky returns #NUM! If matrix does not contain an equal number of columns and rows, CHOLESKY returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: binomial coefficient

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COMBIN returns the binomial coefficient "n choose k", the number of k-combinations of an n-element set without repetition.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If n is less than k COMBIN returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: the number of k-combinations of an n-element set with repetition
the cosine of x

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: SIN, TAN, SINH, COSH, TANH, RADIANS, DEGREES.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic cosine of x
the cosine of Pi*x
the cotangent of x
the hyperbolic cotangent of x
count of the cells meeting the given criteria

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: criteria: condition for a cell to be counted

refnamediv.refpurpose: the cosecant of x

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is not Excel compatible.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: SIN, COS, TAN, SEC, SINH, COSH, TANH, RADIANS, DEGREES.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the hyperbolic cosecant of x

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: This function is not Excel compatible.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: SIN, COS, TAN, CSC, SEC, SINH, COSH, TANH.

refnamediv.refpurpose: equivalent degrees to x radians
eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the symmetric matrix

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If matrix is not symmetric, EIGEN returns #NUM! If matrix does not contain an equal number of columns and rows, EIGEN returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: x rounded away from 0 to the next even integer
e raised to the power of x

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: e is the base of the natural logarithm.

refnamediv.refpurpose: EXP(x)-1

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This function has a higher resulting precision than evaluating EXP(x)-1.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the factorial of x, i.e. x!

If d is less than zero, x is rounded toward 0 to the left of the decimal point

refnamediv.refpurpose: x rounded away from 0

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If d is greater than zero, x is rounded away from 0 to the given number of digits.
If d is zero, x is rounded away from 0 to the next integer.
If d is less than zero, x is rounded away from 0 to the left of the decimal point

refsect1.title: Note

refnamediv.refpurpose: random variate from a skew-normal distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: 𝛼: shape parameter of the skew-normal distribution, defaults to 0
𝜉: location parameter of the skew-normal distribution, defaults to 0
𝜔: scale parameter of the skew-normal distribution, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The random variates are drawn from a skew-normal distribution with shape parameter 𝛼. When 𝛼=0, the skewness vanishes, and we obtain the standard normal density; as 𝛼 increases (in absolute value), the skewness of the distribution increases; when 𝛼 approaches infinity the density converges to the so-called half-normal (or folded normal) density function; if the sign of 𝛼 changes, the density is reflected on the opposite side of the vertical axis.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: The mean of a skew-normal distribution with location parameter 𝜉=0 is not 0. The standard deviation of a skew-normal distribution with scale parameter 𝜔=1 is not 1. The skewness of a skew-normal distribution is in general not 𝛼. If 𝜔 < 0, RANDSNORM returns #NUM!

refnamediv.refpurpose: one of the values in the given argument list depending on the round number of the simulation tool

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SIMTABLE returns one of the values in the given argument list depending on the round number of the simulation tool. When the simulation tool is not activated, SIMTABLE returns d1.

With the simulation tool and the SIMTABLE function you can test given decision variables. Each SIMTABLE function contains the possible values of a simulation variable. In most valid simulation models you should have the same number of values dN for all decision variables. If the simulation is run more rounds than there are values defined, SIMTABLE returns #N/A! error (e.g. if A1 contains `=SIMTABLE(1)' and A2 `=SIMTABLE(1,2)', A1 yields #N/A! error on the second round).

The successive use of the simulation tool also requires that you give to the tool at least one input variable having RAND() or any other RAND<distribution name>() function in it. On each round, the simulation tool iterates for the given number of rounds over all the input variables to reevaluate them. On each iteration, the values of the output variables are stored, and when the round is completed, descriptive statistical information is created according to the values.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GROWTH function applies the “least squares” method to fit an exponential curve to your data and predicts the exponential growth by using this curve.
GROWTH returns an array having one column and a row for each data point in new_xs.
