refnamediv.refpurpose: multiple linear regression coefficients and statistics

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: known_ys: vector of values of dependent variable
known_xs: array of values of independent variables, defaults to a single vector {1,…,n}
affine: if true, the model contains a constant term, defaults to true
stats: if true, some additional statistics are provided, defaults to false

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array with the first row giving the regression coefficients for the independent variables x_m, x_(m-1),…,x_2, x_1 followed by the y-intercept if affine is true.

If stats is true, the second row contains the corresponding standard errors of the regression coefficients.In this case, the third row contains the R^2 value and the standard error for the predicted value. The fourth row contains the observed F value and its degrees of freedom. Finally, the fifth row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.
If affine is false, R^2 is the uncentered version of the coefficient of determination; that is the proportion of the sum of squares explained by the model.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the length of known_ys does not match the corresponding length of known_xs, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Lilliefors (Kolmogorov-Smirnov) Test of Normality

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array with the first row giving the p-value of the Lilliefors (Kolmogorov-Smirnov) Test, the second row the test statistic of the test, and the third the number of observations in the sample.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If there are less than 5 sample values, LKSTEST returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: exponential least square fit

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: known_xs: known x-values; default to an array {1, 2, 3, …}
affine: if true, the model contains a constant term, defaults to true
stat: if true, extra statistical information will be returned; defaults to FALSE

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGEST function applies the “least squares” method to fit an exponential curve of the form y = b * m{1}^x{1} * m{2}^x{2}... to your data.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Extra statistical information is written below the regression line coefficients in the result array. Extra statistical information consists of four rows of data. In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m1, (m2, ...), b are represented. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares. If known_ys and known_xs have unequal number of data points, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: logarithmic least square fit (using a trial and error method)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGFIT function applies the “least squares” method to fit the logarithmic equation y = a + b * ln(sign * (x - c)) , sign = +1 or -1 to your data. The graph of the equation is a logarithmic curve moved horizontally by c and possibly mirrored across the y-axis (if sign = -1).
LOGFIT returns an array having five columns and one row. `Sign' is given in the first column, `a', `b', and `c' are given in columns 2 to 4. Column 5 holds the sum of squared residuals.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: An error is returned when there are less than 3 different x's or y's, or when the shape of the point cloud is too different from a ``logarithmic'' one. You can use the above formula = a + b * ln(sign * (x - c)) or rearrange it to = (exp((y - a) / b)) / sign + c to compute unknown y's or x's, respectively. This is non-linear fitting by trial-and-error. The accuracy of `c' is: width of x-range -> rounded to the next smaller (10^integer), times 0.000001. There might be cases in which the returned fit is not the best possible.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the logarithmic regression

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: known_xs: known x-values; defaults to the array {1, 2, 3, …}
affine: if true, the model contains a constant term, defaults to true
stat: if true, extra statistical information will be returned; defaults to FALSE

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGREG function transforms your x's to z=ln(x) and applies the “least squares” method to fit the linear equation y = m * z + b to your y's and z's --- equivalent to fitting the equation y = m * ln(x) + b to y's and x's. LOGREG returns an array having two columns and one row. m is given in the first column and b in the second.

Any extra statistical information is written below m and b in the result array. This extra statistical information consists of four rows of data: In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m, b are given. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.The default of stat is FALSE.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_ys and known_xs have unequal number of data points, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: rank of a number in a list of numbers

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: number whose rank you want to find
order: 0 (descending order) or non-zero (ascending order); defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In case of a tie, RANK returns the largest possible rank.

refnamediv.refpurpose: rank of a number in a list of numbers

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: x: number whose rank you want to find
order: 0 (descending order) or non-zero (ascending order); defaults to 0

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In case of a tie, RANK returns the average rank.

refnamediv.refpurpose: probability density function of the Rayleigh distribution
probability density function of the Rayleigh tail distribution
square of the Pearson correlation coefficient of the paired set of data

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CORREL, COVAR, INTERCEPT, LINEST, LOGEST, PEARSON, SLOPE, STEYX, TREND.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Shapiro-Francia Test of Normality

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array with the first row giving the p-value of the Shapiro-Francia Test, the second row the test statistic of the test, and the third the number of observations in the sample.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If there are less than 5 or more than 5000 sample values, SFTEST returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: unbiased estimate for skewness of a distribution

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This is only meaningful if the underlying distribution really has a third moment. The skewness of a symmetric (e.g., normal) distribution is zero. If less than three numbers are given, this function returns a #DIV/0! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: population skewness of a data set

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If less than two numbers are given, SKEWP returns a #DIV/0! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the slope of a linear regression line

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_xs or known_ys contains no data entries or different number of data entries, this function returns a #N/A error. If the variance of the known_xs is zero, this function returns #DIV/0 error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: k-th smallest value in a data set

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If data set is empty this function returns a #NUM! error. If k <= 0 or k is greater than the number of data items given this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: probability of the standard normal distribution over an interval

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the cumulative probability over a range of the standard normal distribution; that is the integral over the probability density function from x1 to x2.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x1>x2, this function returns a negative value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: median for grouped data

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: interval: length of each grouping interval, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The data are assumed to be grouped into intervals of width interval. Each data point in array is the midpoint of the interval containing the true value. The median is calculated by interpolation within the median interval (the interval containing the median value), assuming that the true values within that interval are distributed uniformly:
L = the lower limit of the median interval
N = the total number of data points
CF = the number of data points below the median interval
F = the number of data points in the median interval

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If array is empty, this function returns a #NUM! error. If interval <= 0, this function returns a #NUM! error. SSMEDIAN does not check whether the data points are at least interval apart.

refnamediv.refpurpose: z-score of a value

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: mean: mean of the original distribution
stddev: standard deviation of the original distribution

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If stddev is 0 this function returns a #DIV/0! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: sample standard deviation of the given sample

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEV is also known as the N-1-standard deviation.
To obtain the population standard deviation of a whole population use STDEVP.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: AVERAGE, DSTDEV, DSTDEVP, STDEVA, STDEVPA, VAR.

refnamediv.refpurpose: sample standard deviation of the given sample

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEVA is also known as the N-1-standard deviation.
To obtain the population standard deviation of a whole population use STDEVPA.

Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: population standard deviation of the given population

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is also known as the N-standard deviation

refnamediv.refpurpose: population standard deviation of an entire population

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is also known as the N-standard deviation

Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: standard error of the predicted y-value in the regression

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If known_ys and known_xs are empty or have a different number of arguments then this function returns a #N/A error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the subtotal of the given list of arguments

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: function_nbr: determines which function to use according to the following table:

refnamediv.refpurpose: survival function of the Student t-distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: dof: number of degrees of freedom

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The survival function is 1 minus the cumulative distribution function.
This function is Excel compatible for non-negative x.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If dof < 1 this function returns a #NUM! error. If tails is neither 1 or 2 this function returns a #NUM! error. The parameterization of this function is different from what is used for, e.g., NORMSDIST. This is a common source of mistakes, but necessary for compatibility.

refnamediv.refpurpose: two tailed inverse of the Student t-distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: dof: number of degrees of freedom

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the non-negative value x such that the area under the Student t density with dof degrees of freedom to the right of x is p/2.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If p < 0 or p > 1 or dof < 1 this function returns a #NUM! error. The parameterization of this function is different from what is used for, e.g., NORMSINV. This is a common source of mistakes, but necessary for compatibility.

refnamediv.refpurpose: estimates future values of a given data set using a least squares approximation

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: known_ys: vector of values of dependent variable
known_xs: array of values of independent variables, defaults to a single vector {1,…,n}
new_xs: array of x-values for which to estimate the y-values; defaults to known_xs
affine: if true, the model contains a constant term, defaults to true

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the length of known_ys does not match the corresponding length of known_xs, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: mean of the interior of a data set

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: ref: list of numbers whose mean you want to calculate
fraction: fraction of the data set excluded from the mean

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If fraction=0.2 and the data set contains 40 numbers, 8 numbers are trimmed from the data set (40 x 0.2): the 4 largest and the 4 smallest. To avoid a bias, the number of points to be excluded is always rounded down to the nearest even number.

refnamediv.refpurpose: p-value for a hypothesis test comparing the means of two populations using the Student t-distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: array1: sample from the first population
array2: sample from the second population
tails: number of tails to consider
type: Type of test to perform. 1 indicates a test for paired variables, 2 a test of unpaired variables with equal variances, and 3 a test of unpaired variables with unequal variances

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If the data sets contain a different number of data points and the test is paired (type one), TTEST returns the #N/A error. tails and type are truncated to integers. If tails is not one or two, this function returns a #NUM! error. If type is any other than one, two, or three, this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: sample variance of the given sample

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VAR is also known as the N-1-variance.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Since the N-1-variance includes Bessel's correction, whereas the N-variance calculated by VARPA or VARP does not, under reasonable conditions the N-1-variance is an unbiased estimator of the variance of the population from which the sample is drawn.

refnamediv.refpurpose: sample variance of the given sample

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARA is also known as the N-1-variance.
To get the true variance of a complete population use VARPA.

Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: Since the N-1-variance includes Bessel's correction, whereas the N-variance calculated by VARPA or VARP does not, under reasonable conditions the N-1-variance is an unbiased estimator of the variance of the population from which the sample is drawn.

refnamediv.refpurpose: variance of an entire population

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARP is also known as the N-variance.

refnamediv.refpurpose: variance of an entire population

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARPA is also known as the N-variance.

Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: probability density or cumulative distribution function of the Weibull distribution

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: cumulative: whether to evaluate the density function or the cumulative distribution function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If the cumulative boolean is true it will return: 1 - exp (-(x/beta)^alpha),otherwise it will return (alpha/beta^alpha) * x^(alpha-1) * exp(-(x/beta^alpha)).

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If x < 0 this function returns a #NUM! error. If alpha <= 0 or beta <= 0 this function returns a #NUM! error.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the probability of observing a sample mean as large as or larger than the mean of the given sample

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: stddev: population standard deviation, defaults to the sample standard deviation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ZTEST calculates the probability of observing a sample mean as large as or larger than the mean of the given sample for samples drawn from a normal distribution with mean x and standard deviation stddev.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: If ref contains less than two data items ZTEST returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CONFIDENCE, NORMDIST, NORMINV, NORMSDIST, NORMSINV, STANDARDIZE.

refnamediv.refpurpose: text with full-width katakana and ASCII characters converted to half-width

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASC converts full-width katakana and ASCII characters to half-width equivalent characters, copying all others.
The distinction between half-width and full-width characters is described in http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr11/.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While in obsolete encodings ASC used to translate between 2-byte and 1-byte characters, this is not the case in UTF-8.

refsect1.title: Microsoft Excel Compatibility
refsect1.para: For most strings, this function has the same effect as in Excel.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the CP1252 (Windows-1252) character for the code point x

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHAR(x) returns the CP1252 (Windows-1252) character with code x.
x must be in the range 1 to 255.
CP1252 (Windows-1252) is also known as the "ANSI code page", but it is not an ANSI standard.

CP1252 (Windows-1252) is based on an early draft of ISO-8859-1, and contains all of its printable characters. It also contains all of ISO-8859-15's printable characters (but partially at different positions.)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In CP1252 (Windows-1252), 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 do not have matching characters. For x from 1 to 255 except 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 we have CODE(CHAR(x))=x.

refnamediv.refpurpose: text with any non-printable characters removed

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CLEAN removes non-printable characters from its argument leaving only regular characters and white-space.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the CP1252 (Windows-1252) code point for the character c

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: c must be a valid CP1252 (Windows-1252) character.
CP1252 (Windows-1252) is also known as the "ANSI code page", but it is not an ANSI standard.
CP1252 (Windows-1252) is based on an early draft of ISO-8859-1, and contains all of its printable characters (but partially at different positions.)

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: In CP1252 (Windows-1252), 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 do not have matching characters. For x from 1 to 255 except 129, 141, 143, 144, and 157 we have CODE(CHAR(x))=x.

refnamediv.refpurpose: text with half-width katakana and ASCII characters converted to full-width

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: JIS converts half-width katakana and ASCII characters to full-width equivalent characters, copying all others.
The distinction between half-width and full-width characters is described in http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr11/.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: While in obsolete encodings JIS used to translate between 1-byte and 2-byte characters, this is not the case in UTF-8.

refsect1.para: For most strings, this function has the same effect as in Excel.

refnamediv.refpurpose: the location of the search string within text after position start

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: search may contain wildcard characters (*) and question marks (?). A question mark matches any single character, and a wildcard matches any string including the empty string. To search for * or ?, precede the symbol with ~.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This search is not case sensitive. If search is not found, SEARCH returns #VALUE! If start is less than one or it is greater than the length of text, SEARCH returns #VALUE!

refnamediv.refpurpose: the location of the search string within text after byte position start

refsect1.title: Arguments
refsect1.para: start: starting byte position, defaults to 1

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: search may contain wildcard characters (*) and question marks (?). A question mark matches any single character, and a wildcard matches any string including the empty string. To search for * or ?, precede the symbol with ~.

refsect1.title: Note
refsect1.para: This search is not case sensitive. If search is not found, SEARCHB returns #VALUE! If start is less than one or it is greater than the byte length of text, SEARCHB returns #VALUE! The semantics of this function is subject to change as various applications implement it.
